data.text: Build Up Stamina to Go on Long Distance Bike Tours?

Hi everyone - I am interested in building up to bicycle touring, but to say I’m a beginner is an understatement. I’m curious to hear how others got started. How did you build up stamina to be able to go on long distance tours? Did anyone follow any kind of plan? I’d welcome any and all advice:) I’m 49 and while I exercise, I have never been a huge athlete. Thanks! ❤️🚴❤️
Ride a bike, ride a bike, ride a bike...
data.author: Peter South

data.text: love this! I have bike paths near my house and have been trying to ride, but I don’t seem to be able to go for long. I suppose I need to up my frequency!! 🙂
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: , or perhaps go farther but start out less often and then increase frequency.
data.author: Martha Doran

data.text: You don't have to do big distances per day. Just relax, ride until you want to stop. But just start off with an overnighter not too far from home, then build up from there.
data.author: Ian Stapo

data.text: that’s a good idea. Thank you!!!!
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: start slowly ,baby steps ,go on a small over night tour(40 to 60 KM) , my first ride was 80Km and was hard ,a couple of years after I cycled 394 KM in 2 days and a half with a fully loaded bicycle in the big Sahara!!!!!!, Safe Travels and Happy Cycling 🙂 😉 🙂
data.author: Robert Mrki

data.text: wow. That’s very inspiring!!
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: Ride a bike. Choose a distance to work up to. Start easy say 10 miles. Bike everyday with one rest day until you reach that goal. Once you've done that increase that goal by 50% rinse and repeat.
data.author: Shane Daly

data.text: thanks Shane! This is super helpful. Having a goal and a plan like that helps. Thanks:)
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: one more thing. Go to a bike shop that cater to touring and get a proper bike fit. Good luck.
data.author: Shane Daly

data.text: I just started riding last month. I started with 1-2 mile rides every few days. Then I got up to 3-4 miles. Today I’m doing anywhere from 7-10 mile rides. Just build up from where you’re at and continue to build slowly. You’ve got this!
data.author: Justin Pelham

data.text: Aw! Love this. That’s just where I am. Thanks so much
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: I use Strava the app too to track my distance. Feel free to follow my rides there. I wish you all the best. I never knew how fun bike riding was until I started.
data.author: Justin Pelham

data.text: thanks Justin! I’ll check it out:)
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: this is exactly how I started building… I remember struggling when I hit 10 miles every day… then I started doing 20 miles once a week just taking my time. It took me 4 hours to ride 20 miles… now I’m riding 40 miles a day and pushing to 60 miles once a week. One other thing I do… I load my bike up with everything I need for an overnighter 2 times a week going on some of my more hilly routes. This helps build the endurance needed for the longer rides
data.author: Mike Rose

data.text: Ohh I should add… 40 miles in a day I’m pushing myself to my limit… 40 miles in under 4 hours I’m averaging about 13 mph. I take a lunch stop around the 20 mile mark.
data.author: Mike Rose

data.text: No idea where you are but would be surprised if there's not at least one cycling group in the area. Facebook and Meetup are good sources. If you find one group, they'll know of any others nearby. Always great to have co-conspirators & regular ride to coffee is a fun way to get started 😃. Be careful though - can become addictive 😉
data.author: Peter King

data.text: thanks Peter. There are bike riding groups in my area. There’s a meet up and a Facebook group. I’ve been intimidated to join because I’m such a beginner - but that could be a good way to give myself a push￼
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: they will welcome you with open arms and bend your ear with more unsolicited advice than you can poke a stick at 🤣 Go enjoy 👍👍
data.author: Peter King

data.text: I have been riding a little over a year and still feel like a beginner. I joined a group at the beginning of the month knowing I was the weakest link. They slowed their pace down for me but push me to go harder and longer. It’s actually quite rewarding.
data.author: Mike Rose

data.text: From little things, big things grow...
data.author: Richard Neville

data.text: "Vincent was lean, he spoke very little..."
data.author: Peter King

data.text: Touring is FUN! Your riding should be FUN! To motivate yourself set a small weekend “tour” goal, say, 40-50 miles over 2 days. Then work your way up to riding 15-20 miles. Stop along the way for snacks, coffee, photos. Have FUN! Then…GO! You won’t be the fastest, you won’t ride the longest, but you will have FUN! Once you do that you’ll want to go farther. It’s shouldn’t be a suffer-fest although if it were easy everyone would do it! (OBTW, I’m 70 yo)
data.author: Mary Ann Latzgo Padglick

data.text: thanks Mary Ann! I love this. Thanks for the reminder to fold the fun in. I did a ride on my local bike path last week and pooped out right while I was passing a small brewery on the bike path. I’m not a beer drinker , but I ended up ordering myself a charcuterie board – and I would definitely say that was fun! the ride back was tough, but I got home:) ￼
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: when I’m challenging myself I notice the ride back is tough too.
data.author: Bettegail Shively

data.text: Honestly If your in any reasonable shape -been riding a few weeks- enough to have your butt broke into the saddle…. And are willing to let the pace of the ride be as slow as its gonna be (aka not in a big hurry) You dont need to be in any amazing shape. Just know your sustainable pace. And take all the breaks you want through the day:) Barring mountain passes, anybody with their bottom broke into their saddle can typically do 35plus miles in a leisurely day- and have plenty time to get there:) You’ll improve as you go!💕
data.author: Roy Knaak

data.text: Get on a bike and ride....
data.author: Jimmy Duffy

data.text: First time I did an organised fully supported tour, next time a bit less organised, and then worked up to, I've got a map, know where I'm riding to, and have a rough idea of how far I can comfortably ride each day pitch a tent and still enjoy myself.
data.author: Andrea Rose

data.text: thanks Andrea. Riding with gear on a bike sounds so advanced to me right now, but I look forward to getting to that:)￼
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: add something like a small trunk bag with your lunch to start with… and add up from there.
data.author: Mike Rose

data.text: touring bikes also make great errand bikes, try riding the e shop to pick up a few things (start light) it gives you a reason to add weight for a short distance & you’ll be surprised hire easy it is to get used to carrying weight—eventually combine weight & fistance
data.author: Cordelia Min

data.text: two things: 1. ride every chance you get (least 25mi/day), and 2: enjoy the ride! (make it comfy/no rush).
data.author: Eric Mikeska

data.text: P,S, keep it safe by planning your route and let someone know when to expect you
data.author: Eric Mikeska

data.text: Sent you a DM about my journey. Enjoy riding !
data.author: Arabella Watson

data.text: I would start with about 5 miles riding, 3 times a week, flattish terrain to start… Then, after maybe a month of that, move one of the rides to 10 miles, maybe the Saturday ride… Then over the course of the next month, move all 3 weekly rides to 10 miles each. After that, add another ride each week to have 4 rides of 10 miles… keep on that for a month… Then gradually, in 5 mile increments move up that Saturday ride to 15, 20, 25, 30, 40, 50 miles, which would be another 6 weeks… Then, move the other 3 rides each week to 15 miles, and maintain at least one long ride each week at around 50 or more… There’s a plan that if you start in early spring should have you touring by August or September of next year… Just my 2¢…
data.author: Howard Maher

data.text: You don't need to be super fit to tour. It's not a race
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: Where are you based
data.author: Naz Whicker

data.text: No real secret. You ride, stay hydrated, eat well, do a little stretching. If your planning on overnight trips, investigate the various ways to carry what you need. There are tons of YouTube videos that will get you started. Get the gear you think you’ll need and load your bike for some neighborhood rides. Do a few 1-2 nighters to get the feel for it and develop a routine. Then go. Or just buy what you need and go. You’ll get in shape as you go.
data.author: Timothy Dale

data.text: I built my touring bike with myself and it was the first bike, I used park tool chanel on youtube and other. I took my first long trip with my fully loaded bike 6231 km 64 days crossing the Sahara with 0 problems
data.author: غويلب محمد رضا

data.text: Wow, everyone! just messaged me￼ the most inspiring Ted Talk about my exact post… starting! It was incredibly inspiring. I don’t want to share it for her… I’ll leave that to her - but it was moving, motivational and inspiring! Thanks again Arabella (& everyone else for your thoughts:)
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: Thanks Megan
data.author: Arabella Watson

data.text:
Here is the talk if anyone is interested https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lZyyStq67g8
The longest journey starts with a single turn of the pedals. | Arabella Watson | TEDxIpswich
youtube.com
data.author: Arabella Watson

data.text: that just brought a tear to my eyes… thank you
data.author: Simon Edmonds

data.text: thank you
data.author: Arabella Watson

data.text: "> Thank you, Arabella Watson. I really enjoyed watching your TED talk. You are an inspiration.
data.author: Michael Papworth

data.text: Thanks. Been awhile since I have done a really long ride. Melbournes lockdowns for 2 years kind of got in the way. Last one was 12 months ago so time to get back on my bike again
data.author: Arabella Watson

data.text: Personally I am not the greatest athlete and stick to 30 miles a day. Ride at your pace. Speed will come. Do it in small chunks. 5-10-15-20-25-30. Don’t progress too fast.
data.author: Patricia Seifert

data.text: I’m 47, and had no practice before beginning my tour, only a general idea of where I wanted to go and what I wanted to see. I’m not athletic but was a landscaper for many years, so working hard is the norm for me. Joining bike touring groups like this was deflating at first. I started with a goal of 15 miles a day on a 6 speed beach cruiser and added a trailer not long into my ride. I managed to keep between 15 and 35 miles a day until switching to an older mountain bike and losing the trailer (not by choice) and still only make 30-50 miles a day. Seeing others talk about 80-100 mile days had me questioning myself, until I rode 100 miles in a day and realized I didn’t see much of anything compared to my usual pace with lots of stops to take in the amazing views all around me. Now I’m quite happy with my riding, and the shorter distance for me translates to more appreciation of the landscape unfolding around me. Highways and especially interstates are usually good for riding (some states allow it, some don’t). There may be heavy traffic, but you have a wide shoulder to ride on and traffic has plenty of room to avoid you. And the semi trucks may be intimidating but they are (usually) piloted by the safest group of drivers on the road-for them, it’s not just a trip, it’s a career, so they pay attention.
data.author: Nesta Skychild

data.text: 👍. Just to add- it’s supposed to be fun! Riding is a recreational activity at heart- The best ride for you is the one you’re gonna enjoy and want to do again.￼
data.author: Rainer Harstrick

data.text: Just start with little rides then build up each time go a bit further each time
data.author: Tristan Rowland

data.text: Make sure your bike fits you and is in good mechanical condition then straddle your bike and start pedaling. Start at a comfortable pace/distance and keep increasing as your stamina builds. As you gain confidence also learn how to make some repairs. Regarding touring a simple overnight local campground to start. Go on line and start exploring Raols 2 Trails ( maybe safer)? Then start exploring further from home.
data.author: Rick Hancock

data.text: While I started touring at age 26 in Sept 1982 and now at 66 still tour, you don't need to be an athlete to tour. There's no daily certain distance you have to accomplish. While it would take longer to go long distances you can go any you wish. On my first three tours of 2100, 7000 and 1000 miners I went 100 a day, but I was young and full of energy. But soon I decided there was no rush as I started taking 9 months off a year to tour and also go backpacking along the way. By the time I was 30 in 1986 I had gone over 10,000 miles in my first 4 years. I started just riding mornings so I could hike afternoons and taking such routes that brought me through wooded and wild areas like national parks. I toured Sept to November, backpacked till March then bike toured Again till late May when I worked till Labor Day to self support another 3 seasons of bike/hikes. In October I'll begin my 41st seasons of travel.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: Started again last year at 50, try a overnight stay with all your gear not a big distance , and build up gradually , also don’t spend a fortune on kit , you can do that later if you love it as much as I do
data.author: Sean Aspinall-pilgrim

data.text: Ride everyday for a week. See how much easier it is on day 7. On day 8 rest ... It will feel wierd not to get on the bike and ride. You are now ready to tour on a bicycle.
data.author: Mark Tran

data.text: Same boat, no plan, but by bit, exploring local lanes and trails. Doing weekly to daily, ended up at 50km on gravel in Scotland then aches and pains emerged. Got a friend to go over my setup as I was miles out. Better, but broken my routine, roll on autumnal days.
data.author: Fynn Densem

data.text: Definitely plan but be willing to change those plans. I started small but I knew I wanted to do consecutive 100 mile days. So if you haven’t done a century start there. Now that 100 miles isn’t that big a deal, can you do 2 days in a row. My idea is to split the day in 3rds. Mikes are 1 thing but hours are another….8 hours of sleep, 8 hours of cycling & 8 hours whatever else….usually getting ready for the next day.
data.author: Nick Greenwood

data.text: Where are you located? I would love to join in on the training
data.author: Nadine Boszko

data.text: Start small. Focus on cadence. Breathe in… count to whatever…. Until lungs are full. Breathe out… count the same number… until lungs are empty. Repeat. Extend time as your cadence increases
data.author: Aj Sake

data.text: Get a comfortable bicycle and ride it daily. Make your first adventure an easy one. Camping is a skill that you get better at over time….
data.author: David O'Neill

data.text: My wife and I are 47. We started two years ago from scratch. We rode at least three times a week and built up our miles￼ never exceeding the previous weeks total mileage by more than 5%. We usually did one long ride and 2 or 3 short rides. By the end of the year our longest ride was 90 miles￼. We entered a century ride together and it went great. For the past year we have been doing overnighters occasionally and carrying more weight. Tomorrow we leave on our first legitimate tour: 500 miles from San Francisco to LA
data.author: Joseph Heidenreich

data.text: I am not an athlete, for do I have a competitive nature. A friend invited me on a cross state bije trip, Katy trail, with 2 weeks notice. I put together a used bike, 35 year old panniers, and gear from eBay. I went on one 10 mile bike ride before we set off. I had been roller blading about 5 miles/day, so not just hoping off the couch. 365 miles in 6 days, in some very hot, humid weather. The trip was brutal & amazing. And now we go once a year.
data.author: Ashlea Appelbaum

data.text: Set a goal and build up to it. Last year I decided to ride the Erie Canal Buffalo to Albany New York. I am 57 years old and out of shape. I started with 2 miles a night for 2 weeks then on the weekend I would ride 4 miles then 4 miles a night and six on the weekend until I built up to 65 Mi on the weekend. And then I rode the Erie Canal. All of it. Last week I rode the GAP and c&o
data.author: Stephanie Remenek

data.text: I used to ride big mileage and then got a desk job with long hours and lost all my fitness ... and gained almost 100 pounds. Been struggling to get back ever since. You need a couple things, I think---a definite plan fueled by actual desire to do a little better over time ... and also you need to enjoy riding. I find it hard to ride as work ... I want to enjoy my rides, and when I am enjoying riding, it is easier to push a little harder and go \a little longer .... However, some folks just do it on pure discipline, just grind it out ... if you can do that it is faster ..... but once you are on a tour, "grinding it out" is only useful on really bad days .... no point being out in the wonderful world if you are staring at thre road a foot in front of your wheel and hating every pedal-stroke.
data.author: Chris Jasurek

data.text: this makes so much sense. Thank you!!
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: Just pedal. Pedal more and then pedal some more.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: I don't want to oversimplify this, but I'd say that most of my stamina came from pure attitude. I hadn't done any training, nor was I any kind of iron-calfed cyclist when I set out on my first tour -- a hilly 50 mile ride to the next state. I just fixed my mind on it, got on the bike, and went.
data.author: Tom Montalbano

data.text: That works for people who have a certain level of health and fitness. I have a bad heart and asthmatic lungs, and not great muscle tone. I could literally die for pushing myself too hard .... and if I managed 50 hilly miles I probably wouldn't have the physical ability to ride back home. I used to recover really quickly .... lately not so much. I have done a few rides which turned out to be longer than I expected ... and longer than I could do comfortably .... and in most cases it was a week before I was ready to ride again, which meant I got no real fitness gain. It works for some, though .... power to you for the mental fortitude.
data.author: Chris Jasurek

data.text: Just go, go, go. 2 notes for newbies to make a strong start: #1 Camel-up before each interval of ~10 miles. Eat slow carbs like oatmeal or oat bars, drink water by the pint. Take an extra liter/quart of water & slow carbs like oat bars. Ride in a satiated state for high stamina & quick energy. Never start empty intending to make up the difference later, it doesn't work that way. Like filling up your car BEFORE a trip. #2 Plot 20+ mile training routes for the best training effects.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: Just like this... be honest with yourself. You're on your way. Good luck.
data.author: Larry Rampulla

data.text: Cycle-touring is not a sport and you don't need to be an athlete to do it, just curious and able to ride.
data.author: Chris Juden

data.text: Personally I cycled for for say 1/2hour.At first. then increase time gradually. Never worried about distance.Still don't, Cycle mostly off road. Make sure you enjoy yourself.Do what suits you best.ENJOY THE JOURNEY and be safe. Oh and take time to smell the coffee😎🚴‍♀️
data.author: Dave Allen Adi

data.text: The idea that you need to train and fit for long cycle tours is a complete myth. It's not a race, you only have to cycle the distance you are comfortable with each day. Your first day on tour is good training for the second day, the first week is training for the second week, the first month is good training for the second month, and by then you feel as if you can ride forever. Our last three month tour we had not ridden a bike at all for over six months as we had been away working in the Alps. We rode from the UK to the Atlantic coast of France, turned left and rode to Bratislava, then home via Prague, Dresden and Hamburg.
data.author: Robin Symonds

data.text: Just get a bike and ride. Nothing beats time in the saddle.
data.author: Jochen Siegenthaler

data.text: Welcome to the world of ageing limbs and building more strength. Always try to ride within yourself and build your strength gradually. I am 58 and started riding again this year and have recently completed 1000 miles since February. I thought of myself as quite fit but When I first started I struggled to ride 3 miles without stopping. I am now able to ride over 60 miles each day when I tour. You will get there too if you remember to ride within yourself. There are lots of YouTube videos about building your fitness, nutrition and rest. Most of all enjoy your journey 👍👍😎😎
data.author: Guy Burton

data.text: A journey of 10,000 li begins with the first step. --Confucius
data.author: Dee Willis

data.text: Make riding your religion
data.author: Romulo Ignacio

data.text: My boyfriend and I (62 and 69) did our first trip this summer on the GAP, where we could have lodging along the trail and not carry so much. We are not heavy duty long distance cyclists so we did it over 6 days and rode from 11 to 34 miles a day (which seems unheard of in FB posts but it gave us time to hike, explore and rest). We rode our bikes frequently before the trip but not anywhere near the heavy duty training I see recommended. It was a blast! One of the most fun things I've ever done!
data.author: Sylvia Grisez

data.text: I didn't cycle a lot - maybe 500 km a year, even less, on my old road racing bike. And then I decided to cycle from coast to coast. Three weeks before I started, I got the chance to buy a new bike ... and yes, I did the 1600 km ride from the Baltic to the Adriatic Sea in 15 days - that's about 100 km a day.
data.author: Jochen Frank

data.text: Thats it im a bigginer too i started short rides. After a year im riding 40km ones a week, though elevation is still a challenge, i still need lots of it to practice
data.author: Sididang Ako

data.text: i had a plant for this April, as i am 71 wanted to ride Northern Spain to Morocco, caught Covid 19 so that one was put paid to, new plan ride Denmark via Hamburg city center, then onto Berlin via the Baltic coastline with a friend booked Eurotunnel for the car paid travel insurance then 3 days before we were due to leave my friend said he couldn't go..these type of rides could only done with someone accompanying me due to my age and health so hastily cancelled the bookings... and settled for a ride over the north Yorkshire moors all way into Liverpool on my own...As for Morocco its on the cards.......But on my own, wife said don't rely on others cos they let you down and i can do the trip on my own by then its 72 years of age ..
data.author: Raymond Stevens

data.text: So with you on this one I too am 49 and have taking up riding with my husband, a few solos. Really good advice here. Mine is road confidence we live in the countryside which is mainly quiet country roads. We have cycle tracks near us which we use regularly. But really do need to build my distance and confidence on main toads more. Keep going but the main thing is enjoy the ride.
data.author: Kate Smith

data.text: The first 2-3 weeks of your trip will do the job :)
data.author: Robert Mac

data.text: 1/ Create your favorite tour, starting from your home, a ride of about 35 to 50 km, something you can ride in 2 or 3 hours whenever you have a bit of time. 2/ Explore your region by bike. On a Saturday, you just say: I have never been to city X or monument Y, I will go there by bike today. It's a 80 km ride? No worries, just try it. The worst that can happen is that you suffer a bit the last 20 km. 3/ Use an app like Strava to see the progress you're making 4/ Don't take a winter break, buy some good clothing and you will discover sunny winter days are the best for cycling. That's how I built up from being able to ride 60 km to 150 today. It took me two years, I rode my bike about 4 times per month. I am 50 now.
data.author: Gert Corremans

data.text: Start off with short local rides around the neighborhood. Take your bike around town doing errands. Ride on bike trails. Build up your endurance slowly with progressively longer rides and time on the bike. It’s a lifetime process. A marathon not a sprint. Take your time and enjoy yourself.
data.author: Johnny Johnson

data.text: I try for time,+5,+10, slowly slowly catchy fishy.
data.author: GaryGary Sheridan

data.text: If older people such as myself can do it, you can do it!
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: Do lots of squats to ride further. I can’t tell you how much it improved my cycling. Sumo squats are awesome. Then ride a little further each time. Do intervals because riding at a constant pace is not building much of anything. Use proper peddling technique, you’d be surprised what it adds. Ride loaded as practice, and do interval training loaded. Then take off one day and try a short trip. They get longer. Good luck and tailwinds to you!
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: 56 here. Started with short rides of 6 miles and then just started going further and further as I felt able. After 6 months getting out 3 times a week 50 miles had become no trouble and 35 miles routine and felt like a short ride. I'd also lost 25kg in weight. For diet bias towards protein. If you live in a hilly area consider an e-bike to help you on the hills. It takes all of the displeasure and disincentive out of going for a ride. In time you use the battery less and less and then not at all. Plenty of people also tour on e-bikes however. I'm presently on my first tour 800 miles from home with 82 miles to go to my destination.
data.author: Richard Maher

data.text: I started going three days a week, as long as I could. Pretty soon I was at 20 miles. Kept going and three weeks later I went 30, then 40. Once I hit 40 I started touring. Did a solo across the state last year averaging about 50-60 miles a day. 83 was my longest, but it took everything out of me.
data.author: Elisha Hall

data.text: You could do spin classes at a gym. They are great for building up muscle and stamina strength if you can't get out on your bike very often. I use them as a,way to keep fit as don't cycle outside even every week.
data.author: Corinne Lowe McGuckian

data.text: I’m just a few years younger than you and in the same boat. I started by just going, you get fitter quite quickly, but you need to be looking after yourself- eating well, getting decent sleep, lots of rest days - recovery just as important as days on the road. I don’t set distance/time targets, just go with the flow, enjoy the surroundings, new places
data.author: Daniel Hird

data.text: I started with organized tours. They enabled me to understand my own abilities and appetite for adventure. There were often people who'd never done that kind of thing before. I also learned that I preferred a hotel bed to camping.
data.author: Shirley Acreman

data.text: We had a a WS guest stay with us. A girl from England who had never done any real serious cycling. One day she quit her job, bought a bike and she cycled the world. No training but her fitness grew each day as she grew into the bike.
data.author: David O'Donnell

data.text: I am not a bike rider at all,but had a bike. Decided to load it up and go….right across Canada 8400 km. The first day of training was the first day heading west. You just train as you go, the first 3 days are the hardest, you’ll question why the heck you’re doing this, keep going, past day 4 and you’re hooked.
data.author: Susan Stewart

data.text: I was completely under prepared for my first tour, fitness-wise but I just did what I could and my fitness built as the ride went along. Like you I had a certain degree of fitness but I'm inherently lazy, so tended to meander on my ride, and it suited me. It's good to be prepared with the right equipment but I don't think it's essential to be an athlete nor trained to enjoy a tour. I was 57 when I first started, I rode the Altravesur in Spain, well 2/3 of it! Are you planning to ride on or off sealed roads? Just as a note, since my first ride I have done a couple of short rides and tbh I find short rides a lot harder. It's a lot of work packing for a short ride and there's no time to build your fitness. So if you do a short ride don't be downhearted if you find it heavy going, as the longer ride should be easier. I have a blog and YouTube called No Second Season if you want some ideas/advice Good luck🙌
data.author: Angela Hart

data.text: wow, thank you Angela. This is really good to hear
data.author: Megan Elizabeth

data.text: I am 58 and I just embarked on a 2800 km bikepacking journey without any training. Now, after half way into it, I am realizing that I miscalculated a couple of things, including the time frame. I cannot do 100 km a day, with 35kg of equipment, on a constant daily basis and need way more rest than expected. So basically I am down to about 50 km a day on average, which works great for me. You learn while you go and I think you need to find out what works for you. No amount of planning can do that for you.
data.author: Axel Schwekendiek

data.text: Buy a map of u.re area then find some nice places and just visit them take pictures right a blog get out for the day join a club just build the miles up that's all I did ended up racing camping hostelling u name it the club did it loved it even though I.m not in the club anymore it opened up a new world
data.author: Martin Cartwright

data.text: It’s worth considering the ascent you’ll do as well as the distance and time in the saddle. I would plan a weekend trip which is pretty flat, say a canal ride so you can practice riding with a loaded bike and spending several hours in the saddle without the hills to contend with. You can work up from there.
data.author: Catherine Mercer
